question: A uniform magnetic field of strength B = 2 mT exists vertically downwards. These magnetic field lines pass through a closed surface as shown in the figure. The closed surface consists of a hemisphere <katex>$S_1$</katex>, a right circular cone <katex>$S_2$</katex> and a circular surface <katex>$S_3$</katex>. The magnetic flux through <katex>$S_1$</katex> and <katex>$S_2$</katex> are respectively

explanation: Flux entering a closed surface must equal flux leaving if no monopoles exist (Gauss's law for magnetism).
Flux through horizontal circle <katex>$S_3$</katex> (area <katex>$\pi R^2$</katex>): <katex>$\phi = B \cdot A = B(\pi R^2)$</katex>.

Field is downwards. Flux enters <katex>$S_1$</katex> (Hemisphere) and <katex>$S_2$</katex> (Cone) is arranged such that field passes through. Usually, flux entering is negative, leaving is positive. If field is down, it enters top surfaces.
Assuming standard orientation where <katex>$S_1$</katex> is top hemisphere and <katex>$S_2$</katex> is bottom cone: Flux enters <katex>$S_1$</katex> (-20) and leaves <katex>$S_2$</katex> (+20).
